an3.52:1.1.pli: Atha kho dve brāhmaṇā jiṇṇā vuddhā mahallakā addhagatā vayoanuppattā vīsavassasatikā jātiyā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te brāhmaṇā bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
an3.52:1.1.eng: Then two old brahmins—elderly and senior, who were advanced in years and had reached the final stage of life, being a hundred and twenty years old—went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to the Buddha:

an3.52:1.2.pli: “mayamassu, bho gotama, brāhmaṇā jiṇṇā vuddhā mahallakā addhagatā vayoanuppattā vīsavassasatikā jātiyā;
an3.52:1.2.eng: “We brahmins, worthy Gotama, are old, elderly and senior, we’re advanced in years and have reached the final stage of life; we’re a hundred and twenty years old.

an3.52:1.3.eng: And we haven’t done what is good and skillful, nor have we made a shelter from fear.

an3.52:1.4.pli: Ovadatu no bhavaṃ gotamo, anusāsatu no bhavaṃ gotamo yaṃ amhākaṃ assa dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā”ti.
an3.52:1.4.eng: Advise us, worthy Gotama, instruct us! It will be for our lasting welfare and happiness.”

an3.52:2.1.pli: “Taggha tumhe, brāhmaṇā, jiṇṇā vuddhā mahallakā addhagatā vayoanuppattā vīsavassasatikā jātiyā;
an3.52:2.1.eng: “Indeed, brahmins, you’re old, elderly and senior.

an3.52:2.2.eng: And you haven’t done what is good and skillful, nor have you made a shelter from fear.

an3.52:2.3.pli: Āditto kho ayaṃ, brāhmaṇā, loko jarāya byādhinā maraṇena.
an3.52:2.3.eng: This world is burning with old age, sickness, and death.

an3.52:2.4.pli: Evaṃ āditte kho, brāhmaṇā, loke jarāya byādhinā maraṇena, yo idha kāyena saṃyamo vācāya saṃyamo manasā saṃyamo, taṃ tassa petassa tāṇañca leṇañca dīpañca saraṇañca parāyaṇañcāti.
an3.52:2.4.eng: But restraint here by way of body, speech, and mind is the shelter, protection, island, refuge, and haven for the departed.

an3.52:3.1.eng: When your house is on fire,

an3.52:4.1.eng: And as the world is on fire

an3.52:5.4.eng: as the good deeds done while living.”

an3.53:1.1.pli: Atha kho aññataro brāhmaṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi …pe… ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an3.53:1.1.eng: Then a brahmin went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him. Seated to one side he said to the Buddha:

an3.53:1.2.pli: “‘sandiṭṭhiko dhammo sandiṭṭhiko dhammo’ti, bho gotama, vuccati.
an3.53:1.2.eng: “Worthy Gotama, they speak of ‘a teaching apparent in the present life’.

an3.53:1.3.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, bho gotama, sandiṭṭhiko dhammo hoti akāliko ehipassiko opaneyyiko paccattaṃ veditabbo viññūhī”ti?
an3.53:1.3.eng: In what way is the teaching apparent in the present life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves?”

an3.53:2.1.pli: “Ratto kho, brāhmaṇa, rāgena abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto attabyābādhāyapi ceteti, parabyābādhāyapi ceteti, ubhayabyābādhāyapi ceteti, cetasikampi dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti.
an3.53:2.1.eng: “A greedy person, overcome and overwhelmed by greed, intends to hurt themselves, hurt others, and hurt both. They experience mental pain and sadness.

an3.53:2.2.pli: Rāge pahīne nevattabyābādhāyapi ceteti, na parabyābādhāyapi ceteti, na ubhayabyābādhāyapi ceteti, na cetasikaṃ dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti.
an3.53:2.2.eng: When greed has been given up, they don’t intend to hurt themselves, hurt others, and hurt both. They don’t experience mental pain and sadness.

an3.53:2.3.pli: Ratto kho …pe… kāyena duccaritaṃ carati, vācāya duccaritaṃ carati, manasā duccaritaṃ carati.

an3.53:2.4.pli: Rāge pahīne neva kāyena duccaritaṃ carati, na vācāya duccaritaṃ carati, na manasā duccaritaṃ carati.

an3.53:2.5.pli: Ratto kho …pe… attatthampi yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti, paratthampi yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti, ubhayatthampi yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti.

an3.53:2.6.pli: Rāge pahīne attatthampi yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, paratthampi yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ubhayatthampi yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.

an3.53:2.7.pli: Evampi kho, brāhmaṇa, sandiṭṭhiko dhammo hoti …pe….
an3.53:2.7.eng: This is how the teaching is apparent in the present life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.

an3.53:3.1.pli: Duṭṭho kho, brāhmaṇa, dosena abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto attabyābādhāyapi ceteti, parabyābādhāyapi ceteti, ubhayabyābādhāyapi ceteti, cetasikampi dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti.
an3.53:3.1.eng: A hateful person, overcome by hate, intends to hurt themselves, hurt others, and hurt both. They experience mental pain and sadness.

an3.53:3.2.pli: Dose pahīne nevattabyābādhāyapi ceteti, na parabyābādhāyapi ceteti, na ubhayabyābādhāyapi ceteti, na cetasikampi dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti.
an3.53:3.2.eng: When hate has been given up, they don’t intend to hurt themselves, hurt others, and hurt both. They don’t experience mental pain and sadness.

an3.53:3.3.pli: Evampi kho, brāhmaṇa, sandiṭṭhiko dhammo hoti …pe….
an3.53:3.3.eng: This, too, is how the teaching is apparent in the present life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.

an3.53:4.1.pli: Mūḷho kho, brāhmaṇa, mohena abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto attabyābādhāyapi ceteti, parabyābādhāyapi ceteti, ubhayabyābādhāyapi ceteti, cetasikampi dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti.
an3.53:4.1.eng: A deluded person, overcome by delusion, intends to hurt themselves, hurt others, and hurt both. They experience mental pain and sadness.

an3.53:4.2.pli: Mohe pahīne nevattabyābādhāyapi ceteti, na parabyābādhāyapi ceteti, na ubhayabyābādhāyapi ceteti, na cetasikaṃ dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti.
an3.53:4.2.eng: When delusion has been given up, they don’t intend to hurt themselves, hurt others, and hurt both. They don’t experience mental pain and sadness.

an3.53:4.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa, sandiṭṭhiko dhammo hoti akāliko ehipassiko opaneyyiko paccattaṃ veditabbo viññūhī”ti.
an3.53:4.3.eng: This, too, is how the teaching is apparent in the present life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.”

an3.53:5.2.pli: Seyyathāpi, bho gotama, nikkujjitaṃ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṃ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṃ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya: ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evamevaṃ bhotā gotamena anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
an3.53:5.2.eng: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, worthy Gotama has made the teaching clear in many ways.

an3.53:5.3.pli: Esāhaṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
an3.53:5.3.eng: I go for refuge to the worthy Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.

an3.53:5.4.pli: Upāsakaṃ maṃ bhavaṃ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan”ti.
an3.53:5.4.eng: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

an3.54:1.1.pli: Atha kho aññataro brāhmaṇaparibbājako yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā …pe… ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so brāhmaṇaparibbājako bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an3.54:1.1.eng: Then a brahmin wanderer went up to the Buddha … Seated to one side he said to the Buddha:

an3.54:1.2.pli: “‘sandiṭṭhiko dhammo sandiṭṭhiko dhammo’ti, bho gotama, vuccati.
an3.54:1.2.eng: “Worthy Gotama, they speak of ‘a teaching apparent in the present life’.

an3.54:1.3.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, bho gotama, sandiṭṭhiko dhammo hoti akāliko ehipassiko opaneyyiko paccattaṃ veditabbo viññūhī”ti?
an3.54:1.3.eng: In what way is the teaching apparent in the present life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves?”

an3.54:2.1.pli: “Ratto kho, brāhmaṇa, rāgena abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto attabyābādhāyapi ceteti, parabyābādhāyapi ceteti, ubhayabyābādhāyapi ceteti, cetasikampi dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti.
an3.54:2.1.eng: “A greedy person, overcome by greed, intends to hurt themselves, hurt others, and hurt both. They experience mental pain and sadness.

an3.54:2.2.pli: Rāge pahīne nevattabyābādhāyapi ceteti, na parabyābādhāyapi ceteti, na ubhayabyābādhāyapi ceteti, na cetasikampi dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti.
an3.54:2.2.eng: When greed has been given up, they don’t intend to hurt themselves, hurt others, and hurt both. They don’t experience mental pain and sadness.

an3.54:3.1.pli: Ratto kho, brāhmaṇa, rāgena abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto kāyena duccaritaṃ carati, vācāya duccaritaṃ carati, manasā duccaritaṃ carati.
an3.54:3.1.eng: A greedy person does bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.

an3.54:3.2.pli: Rāge pahīne neva kāyena duccaritaṃ carati, na vācāya duccaritaṃ carati, na manasā duccaritaṃ carati.
an3.54:3.2.eng: When greed has been given up, they don’t do bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.

an3.54:4.1.pli: Ratto kho, brāhmaṇa, rāgena abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto attatthampi yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti, paratthampi yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti, ubhayatthampi yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti.
an3.54:4.1.eng: A greedy person doesn’t truly understand what’s for their own good, the good of another, or the good of both.

an3.54:4.2.pli: Rāge pahīne attatthampi yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, paratthampi yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ubhayatthampi yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
an3.54:4.2.eng: When greed has been given up, they truly understand what’s for their own good, the good of another, or the good of both.

an3.54:4.3.pli: Evampi kho, brāhmaṇa, sandiṭṭhiko dhammo hoti …pe….
an3.54:4.3.eng: This is how the teaching is apparent in the present life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.

an3.54:5.2.pli: mūḷho kho, brāhmaṇa, mohena abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto attabyābādhāyapi ceteti, parabyābādhāyapi ceteti, ubhayabyābādhāyapi ceteti, cetasikampi dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti.
an3.54:5.2.eng: A deluded person, overcome by delusion, intends to hurt themselves, hurt others, and hurt both. They experience mental pain and sadness.

an3.54:5.3.pli: Mohe pahīne nevattabyābādhāyapi ceteti, na parabyābādhāyapi ceteti, na ubhayabyābādhāyapi ceteti, na cetasikaṃ dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti.
an3.54:5.3.eng: When delusion has been given up, they don’t intend to hurt themselves, hurt others, and hurt both. They don’t experience mental pain and sadness.

an3.54:6.1.pli: Mūḷho kho, brāhmaṇa, mohena abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto, kāyena duccaritaṃ carati, vācāya duccaritaṃ carati, manasā duccaritaṃ carati.
an3.54:6.1.eng: A deluded person does bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.

an3.54:6.2.pli: Mohe pahīne neva kāyena duccaritaṃ carati, na vācāya duccaritaṃ carati, na manasā duccaritaṃ carati.
an3.54:6.2.eng: When delusion has been given up, they don’t do bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.

an3.54:7.1.pli: Mūḷho kho, brāhmaṇa, mohena abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto attatthampi yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti, paratthampi yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti, ubhayatthampi yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti.
an3.54:7.1.eng: A deluded person doesn’t truly understand what’s for their own good, the good of another, or the good of both.

an3.54:7.2.pli: Mohe pahīne attatthampi yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, paratthampi yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ubhayatthampi yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
an3.54:7.2.eng: When delusion has been given up, they truly understand what’s for their own good, the good of another, or the good of both.

an3.54:7.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa, sandiṭṭhiko dhammo hoti akāliko ehipassiko opaneyyiko paccattaṃ veditabbo viññūhī”ti.
an3.54:7.3.eng: This, too, is how the teaching is apparent in the present life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.”

an3.54:8.2.pli: upāsakaṃ maṃ bhavaṃ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan”ti.
an3.54:8.2.eng: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

an3.55:1.1.pli: Atha kho jāṇussoṇi brāhmaṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho jāṇussoṇi brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an3.55:1.1.eng: Then the brahmin Jānussoṇi went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to the Buddha:

an3.55:1.2.pli: “‘sandiṭṭhikaṃ nibbānaṃ sandiṭṭhikaṃ nibbānan’ti, bho gotama, vuccati.
an3.55:1.2.eng: “Worthy Gotama, they say that ‘extinguishment is apparent in the present life’.

an3.55:1.3.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, bho gotama, sandiṭṭhikaṃ nibbānaṃ hoti akālikaṃ ehipassikaṃ opaneyyikaṃ paccattaṃ veditabbaṃ viññūhī”ti?
an3.55:1.3.eng: In what way is extinguishment apparent in the present life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves?”

an3.55:2.1.pli: Ratto kho, brāhmaṇa, rāgena abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto attabyābādhāyapi ceteti, parabyābādhāyapi ceteti, ubhayabyābādhāyapi ceteti, cetasikampi dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti.
an3.55:2.1.eng: “A greedy person, overcome by greed, intends to hurt themselves, hurt others, and hurt both. They experience mental pain and sadness.

an3.55:2.2.pli: Rāge pahīne nevattabyābādhāyapi ceteti, na parabyābādhāyapi ceteti, na ubhayabyābādhāyapi ceteti, na cetasikampi dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti.
an3.55:2.2.eng: When greed has been given up, they don’t intend to hurt themselves, hurt others, and hurt both. They don’t experience mental pain and sadness.

an3.55:2.3.pli: Evampi kho, brāhmaṇa, sandiṭṭhikaṃ nibbānaṃ hoti.
an3.55:2.3.eng: This is how extinguishment is apparent in the present life.

an3.55:3.2.pli: mūḷho kho, brāhmaṇa, mohena abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto attabyābādhāyapi ceteti, parabyābādhāyapi ceteti, ubhayabyābādhāyapi ceteti, cetasikampi dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti.
an3.55:3.2.eng: A deluded person, overcome by delusion, intends to hurt themselves, hurt others, and hurt both. They experience mental pain and sadness.

an3.55:3.3.pli: Mohe pahīne nevattabyābādhāyapi ceteti, na parabyābādhāyapi ceteti, na ubhayabyābādhāyapi ceteti, na cetasikaṃ dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti.
an3.55:3.3.eng: When delusion has been given up, they don’t intend to hurt themselves, hurt others, and hurt both. They don’t experience mental pain and sadness.

an3.55:3.4.pli: Evampi kho, brāhmaṇa, sandiṭṭhikaṃ nibbānaṃ hoti.
an3.55:3.4.eng: This, too, is how extinguishment is apparent in the present life.

an3.55:4.1.pli: Yato kho ayaṃ, brāhmaṇa, anavasesaṃ rāgakkhayaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti, anavasesaṃ dosakkhayaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti, anavasesaṃ mohakkhayaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti;
an3.55:4.1.eng: When you experience the ending of greed, hate, and delusion without anything left over,

an3.55:4.2.pli: evaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa, sandiṭṭhikaṃ nibbānaṃ hoti akālikaṃ ehipassikaṃ opaneyyikaṃ paccattaṃ veditabbaṃ viññūhī”ti.
an3.55:4.2.eng: that’s how extinguishment is apparent in the present life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.”

an3.55:5.2.pli: upāsakaṃ maṃ bhavaṃ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan”ti.
an3.55:5.2.eng: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

an3.56:1.1.pli: Atha kho aññataro brāhmaṇamahāsālo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami …pe… ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so brāhmaṇamahāsālo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an3.56:1.1.eng: Then a well-to-do Brahmin went up to the Buddha, and seated to one side he said to him:

an3.56:1.2.pli: “sutaṃ metaṃ, bho gotama, pubbakānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ vuddhānaṃ mahallakānaṃ ācariyapācariyānaṃ bhāsamānānaṃ:
an3.56:1.2.eng: “Worthy Gotama, I have heard that brahmins of the past who were elderly and senior, the tutors of tutors, said:

an3.56:1.3.pli: ‘pubbe sudaṃ ayaṃ loko avīci maññe phuṭo ahosi manussehi, kukkuṭasaṃpātikā gāmanigamarājadhāniyo’ti.
an3.56:1.3.eng: ‘In the old days this world was so full of humans you’d think they were squashed together. The villages, towns and capital cities were no more than a chicken’s flight apart.’

an3.56:1.4.pli: Ko nu kho, bho gotama, hetu ko paccayo yenetarahi manussānaṃ khayo hoti, tanuttaṃ paññāyati, gāmāpi agāmā honti, nigamāpi anigamā honti, nagarāpi anagarā honti, janapadāpi ajanapadā hontī”ti?
an3.56:1.4.eng: What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why these days human numbers have dwindled, a decline in population is evident, and whole villages, towns, cities, and countries have disappeared?”

an3.56:2.1.eng: “These days, brahmin, humans just love illicit desire. They’re overcome by immoral greed, and mired in wrong custom.

an3.56:2.2.pli: Te adhammarāgarattā visamalobhābhibhūtā micchādhammaparetā tiṇhāni satthāni gahetvā aññamaññaṃ jīvitā voropenti, tena bahū manussā kālaṃ karonti.
an3.56:2.2.eng: Taking up sharp knives, they murder each other. And so many people perish.

an3.56:2.3.pli: Ayampi kho, brāhmaṇa, hetu ayaṃ paccayo yenetarahi manussānaṃ khayo hoti, tanuttaṃ paññāyati, gāmāpi agāmā honti, nigamāpi anigamā honti, nagarāpi anagarā honti, janapadāpi ajanapadā honti.
an3.56:2.3.eng: This is the cause, this is the reason why these days human numbers have dwindled.

an3.56:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, brāhmaṇa, etarahi manussā adhammarāgarattā visamalobhābhibhūtā micchādhammaparetā.
an3.56:3.1.eng: Furthermore, because these days humans just love illicit desire …

an3.56:3.2.pli: Tesaṃ adhammarāgarattānaṃ visamalobhābhibhūtānaṃ micchādhammaparetānaṃ devo na sammādhāraṃ anuppavecchati.
an3.56:3.2.eng: the heavens don’t provide enough rain,

an3.56:3.3.pli: Tena dubbhikkhaṃ hoti dussassaṃ setaṭṭhikaṃ salākāvuttaṃ.
an3.56:3.3.eng: so there’s famine, a bad harvest, with blighted crops that turn to straw.

an3.56:3.5.pli: Ayampi kho, brāhmaṇa, hetu ayaṃ paccayo yenetarahi manussānaṃ khayo hoti, tanuttaṃ paññāyati, gāmāpi agāmā honti, nigamāpi anigamā honti, nagarāpi anagarā honti, janapadāpi ajanapadā honti.
an3.56:3.5.eng: This is the cause, this is the reason why these days human numbers have dwindled.

an3.56:4.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, brāhmaṇa, etarahi manussā adhammarāgarattā visamalobhābhibhūtā micchādhammaparetā.
an3.56:4.1.eng: Furthermore, because these days humans just love illicit desire …

an3.56:4.2.pli: Tesaṃ adhammarāgarattānaṃ visamalobhābhibhūtānaṃ micchādhammaparetānaṃ yakkhā vāḷe amanusse ossajjanti, tena bahū manussā kālaṃ karonti.
an3.56:4.2.eng: native spirits let vicious monsters loose. And so many humans perish.

an3.56:4.3.pli: Ayampi kho, brāhmaṇa, hetu ayaṃ paccayo yenetarahi manussānaṃ khayo hoti, tanuttaṃ paññāyati, gāmāpi agāmā honti, nigamāpi anigamā honti, nagarāpi anagarā honti, janapadāpi ajanapadā hontī”ti.
an3.56:4.3.eng: This is the cause, this is the reason why these days human numbers have dwindled.”

an3.56:5.2.pli: upāsakaṃ maṃ bhavaṃ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan”ti.
an3.56:5.2.eng: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

an3.57:1.1.pli: Atha kho vacchagotto paribbājako yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
an3.57:1.1.eng: Then the wanderer Vacchagotta went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

an3.57:1.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho vacchagotto paribbājako bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an3.57:1.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha:

an3.57:1.3.pli: “sutaṃ metaṃ, bho gotama, samaṇo gotamo evamāha:
an3.57:1.3.eng: “I have heard, worthy Gotama, that the ascetic Gotama says this:

an3.57:1.4.eng: ‘Gifts should only be given to me, not to others.

an3.57:1.5.pli: mayhameva sāvakānaṃ dānaṃ dātabbaṃ, nāññesaṃ sāvakānaṃ dānaṃ dātabbaṃ;
an3.57:1.5.eng: Gifts should only be given to my disciples, not to the disciples of others.

an3.57:1.6.pli: mayhameva dinnaṃ mahapphalaṃ, nāññesaṃ dinnaṃ mahapphalaṃ;
an3.57:1.6.eng: Only what is given to me is very fruitful, not what is given to others.

an3.57:1.7.pli: mayhameva sāvakānaṃ dinnaṃ mahapphalaṃ, nāññesaṃ sāvakānaṃ dinnaṃ mahapphalan’ti.
an3.57:1.7.eng: Only what is given to my disciples is very fruitful, not what is given to the disciples of others.’

an3.57:1.8.pli: Ye te, bho gotama, evamāhaṃsu ‘samaṇo gotamo evamāha:

an3.57:1.10.pli: Mayhameva sāvakānaṃ dānaṃ dātabbaṃ, nāññesaṃ sāvakānaṃ dānaṃ dātabbaṃ.

an3.57:1.11.pli: Mayhameva dinnaṃ mahapphalaṃ, nāññesaṃ dinnaṃ mahapphalaṃ.

an3.57:1.12.pli: Mayhameva sāvakānaṃ dinnaṃ mahapphalaṃ, nāññesaṃ sāvakānaṃ dinnaṃ mahapphalan”’ti.

an3.57:1.13.pli: Kacci te bhoto gotamassa vuttavādino na ca bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ abhūtena abbhācikkhanti, dhammassa cānudhammaṃ byākaronti, na ca koci sahadhammiko vādānupāto gārayhaṃ ṭhānaṃ āgacchati?
an3.57:1.13.eng: I trust that those who say this repeat what the Buddha has said, and do not misrepresent him with an untruth? Is their explanation in line with the teaching? Are there any legitimate grounds for rebuttal and criticism?

an3.57:1.14.eng: For we don’t want to misrepresent the worthy Gotama.”

an3.57:2.5.pli: na me te vuttavādino. Abbhācikkhanti ca pana maṃ asatā abhūtena.
an3.57:2.5.eng: do not repeat what I have said. They misrepresent me with what is false and untrue.

an3.57:2.6.pli: Yo kho, vaccha, paraṃ dānaṃ dadantaṃ vāreti so tiṇṇaṃ antarāyakaro hoti, tiṇṇaṃ pāripanthiko.
an3.57:2.6.eng: Anyone who prevents another from giving makes an obstacle and a roadblock for three individuals.

an3.57:2.8.pli: Dāyakassa puññantarāyakaro hoti, paṭiggāhakānaṃ lābhantarāyakaro hoti, pubbeva kho panassa attā khato ca hoti upahato ca.
an3.57:2.8.eng: The giver is obstructed from making merit. The receiver is obstructed from getting what is offered. And they’ve already broken and damaged themselves.

an3.57:2.9.pli: Yo kho, vaccha, paraṃ dānaṃ dadantaṃ vāreti so imesaṃ tiṇṇaṃ antarāyakaro hoti, tiṇṇaṃ pāripanthiko.
an3.57:2.9.eng: Anyone who prevents another from giving makes an obstacle and a roadblock for these three individuals.

an3.57:3.1.pli: Ahaṃ kho pana, vaccha, evaṃ vadāmi:
an3.57:3.1.eng: Vaccha, this is what I say:

an3.57:3.2.pli: ‘ye hi te candanikāya vā oligalle vā pāṇā, tatrapi yo thālidhovanaṃ vā sarāvadhovanaṃ vā chaḍḍeti:
an3.57:3.2.eng: ‘You even make merit by tipping out dish-washing water in a cesspool or a sump with living creatures in it, thinking,

an3.57:3.3.pli: “ye tattha pāṇā te tena yāpentū”’ti, tato nidānampāhaṃ, vaccha, puññassa āgamaṃ vadāmi.

an3.57:3.4.eng: How much more then for human beings!

an3.57:3.5.pli: Api cāhaṃ, vaccha, sīlavato dinnaṃ mahapphalaṃ vadāmi, no tathā dussīlassa, so ca hoti pañcaṅgavippahīno pañcaṅgasamannāgato.
an3.57:3.5.eng: However, I also say that a gift to an ethical person is more fruitful than one to an unethical person. They’ve given up five factors, and possess five factors.

an3.57:4.1.eng: What are the five factors they’ve given up?

an3.57:4.2.pli: Kāmacchando pahīno hoti, byāpādo pahīno hoti, thinamiddhaṃ pahīnaṃ hoti, uddhaccakukkuccaṃ pahīnaṃ hoti, vicikicchā pahīnā hoti.
an3.57:4.2.eng: Sensual desire, ill will, dullness and drowsiness, restlessness and remorse, and doubt.

an3.57:4.3.eng: These are the five factors they’ve given up.

an3.57:5.1.eng: What are the five factors they possess?

an3.57:5.2.pli: Asekkhena sīlakkhandhena samannāgato hoti, asekkhena samādhikkhandhena samannāgato hoti, asekkhena paññākkhandhena samannāgato hoti, asekkhena vimuttikkhandhena samannāgato hoti, asekkhena vimuttiñāṇadassanakkhandhena samannāgato hoti;
an3.57:5.2.eng: The entire spectrum of an adept’s ethics, immersion, wisdom, freedom, and knowledge and vision of freedom.

an3.57:5.3.eng: These are the five factors they possess.

an3.57:5.4.pli: Iti pañcaṅgavippahīne pañcaṅgasamannāgate dinnaṃ mahapphalanti vadāmīti.
an3.57:5.4.eng: I say that a gift to anyone who has given up these five factors and possesses these five factors is very fruitful.

an3.57:6.1.eng: Cows may be black or white,

an3.57:7.1.eng: But when one is born among them,

an3.57:7.5.eng: they yoke the load just to him,

an3.57:9.3.eng: Firm in principle, accomplished in ethical conduct,

an3.57:10.1.eng: they’ve given up birth and death.

an3.57:10.4.eng: they’ve completed the task <j>and are free of defilements.

an3.57:12.3.eng: give their gifts to those outside,

an3.57:12.4.eng: and don’t attend the peaceful ones.

an3.57:13.1.eng: But those who do attend the peaceful ones—

an3.57:13.3.eng: and whose faith in the Holy One

an3.57:14.1.eng: they go to the realm of the gods,

an3.57:14.2.eng: or are born here in a good family.
